docs.snippet: For all the virtues that today’s social networks offer us, the inability to categorize friends online has become increasingly frustrating. Google+ hopes to offer a solution to this problem....
docs.lead_paragraph: I don’t consider my neighbor my “friend.” My boss isn’t necessarily my “friend” either (although I do like my boss!). I also wouldn’t categorize a person I met 20 years ago in high school as my “friend.” Yet on social Web sites like Facebook these people are all lumped into one giant social bucket called “friends.”

headline.main: Organizing My Online Friends

docs.snippet: Waiting for Amazon to sell a full-fledged tablet feels like waiting for the grass to grow: we know it's going to happen, but it's taking an awfully long time.     As we have reported over the last year, Amazon has been readying a color screen tabl...
docs.lead_paragraph: Waiting for Amazon to sell a full-fledged tablet feels like waiting for the grass to grow: we know it's going to happen, but it's taking an awfully long time. As we have reported over the last year, Amazon has been readying a color screen tablet that will run the Google Android operating system. Jeff Bezos, Amazon's chief executive, has even acknowledged that a tablet project is in the works, saying earlier this year that the company was actively working on a ''multipurpose tablet device.''

headline.main: Amazon Debate: Android or Not?

docs.abstract: Bits blog notes Amazon is apparently readying color screen tablet that will most likely run on Google Android operating system (S)

docs.snippet: Google allows us to “save hard drive space for what matters, while at the same time improving the accuracy of recall.”...
docs.lead_paragraph: Why is your brain on Google better than your brain sans Google? Because it gives you somewhere to store all that trivia you would otherwise have to waste precious brain cells remembering. Or so says Jonah Lehrer, via Andrew Sullivan on the Daily Dish, who points out that Google not only helps us remember but also helps us correct our often faulty memories. “While the Web enables all sorts of other biases – it lets us filter news, for instance, to confirm what we already believe – the use of the Web as a vessel of transactive memory is mostly virtuous. We save hard drive space for what matters, while at the same time improving the accuracy of recall.” So forget all those warnings about how the Web just makes us dumber. It’s perfectly okay if you have to Google something you just read two seconds ago.

headline.main: Does Google Make Us Smarter, Dumber or Both?

docs.abstract: Google allows us to “save hard drive space for what matters, while at the same time improving the accuracy of recall.”

docs.lead_paragraph: In the war to own the social Web, Google is building up its arsenal. The company has bought Fridge, a social network service, to complement Google Plus. “We strongly believe in the group social experience and couldn’t think of a better place to realize our vision of bringing the nuance and richness of real-life sharing to the web as part of the Google+ Project,” the company said on its blog on Thursday. Read more »

headline.main: Google Buys Social Site Fridge

docs.abstract: In the war to own the social Web, Google is building up its arsenal. The company has bought Fridge, a social network service, to complement Google Plus. “We strongly believe in the group social experience and couldn’t think of a better place to realize our vision of bringing the nuance and richness of real-life sharing to the web as part of the Google+ Project,” the company said on its blog on Thursday. Read more »

docs.lead_paragraph: Desktop shortcuts can save time, and the Google Chrome browser includes a feature to quickly create shortcuts for your most frequently used Web sites and apps. To make one for a site or an app in the Chrome window, click the wrench icon in the toolbar, go to the Tools menu and choose the “Create application shortcuts” option. Select where on the computer you want to store the shortcut (like the desktop, Start menu or taskbar) and click the Create button.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Making Shortcuts in Chrome

docs.snippet: The New York Times Company's About Group, which publishes the advice and informational Web site About.com, has appointed a new chief executive.     Darline Jean, formerly About's chief financial officer, will take over the top position on Sept. 1,...
docs.lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company's About Group, which publishes the advice and informational Web site About.com, has appointed a new chief executive. Darline Jean, formerly About's chief financial officer, will take over the top position on Sept. 1, the company said Tuesday. The appointment was part of a broader management shuffle at the company in which new heads for the sales and finance divisions were also named.About has been struggling with declining revenue and Web traffic since Google changed both the way it directs traffic to informational sites like About.com and the way it allows those sites to collect revenue from ads that users click on. In the second quarter, About's revenues dropped 17.3 percent to $27.8 million.

headline.main: Times Names Chief at Parent Of About.com

docs.abstract: The New York Times Company's About Group appoints Darline Jean as its new chief executive (M)

It’s like, ‘No, this call’s going the wrong way!’”

headline.main: OK Go Finds a Dance Partner

In addition, the band cooked up an interactive feature, built for Google Chrome, where viewers are able to customize their own messages.

docs.snippet: If you want to revisit some memory lanes, at least of the Parker Brothers sort, from back when you were pretty sure you would make a great real estate tycoon when you grew up, then go to Google Maps and plug in the address for the Revel Casino, wh...
docs.lead_paragraph: If you want to revisit some memory lanes, at least of the Parker Brothers sort, from back when you were pretty sure you would make a great real estate tycoon when you grew up, then go to Google Maps and plug in the address for the Revel Casino, which was featured in last weekend’s Look essay. There it is: 500 Boardwalk, Atlantic City, right around the corner from the original Vermont and Oriental Avenues. (Somehow it seems fitting that Morgan Stanley, which lost around a billion dollars on its Revel investment, failed to put the casino on one of the farther-off orange properties, particularly New York Avenue, which, if I read this and this right, is the optimal Monopoly strategy.)

headline.main: Here Comes the Neighborhood

docs.abstract: If you want to revisit some memory lanes, at least of the Parker Brothers sort, from back when you were pretty sure you would make a great real estate tycoon when you grew up, then go to Google Maps and plug in the address for the Revel Casino, which was featured in last weekend’s Look essay.

docs.snippet: Microsoft has invested billions of dollars in Bing, its search engine. But it faces a daunting rival in Google, the giant in search. To compete, Microsoft has focused on aggregating and presenting specific kinds of information in areas like travel...
docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft has invested billions of dollars in Bing, its search engine. But it faces a daunting rival in Google, the giant in search. To compete, Microsoft has focused on aggregating and presenting specific kinds of information in areas like travel, restaurants and recipes as part of a search result. Below is a look at some of the specific ways that Bing is trying to distinguish itself from Google.

headline.seo: A Search Engine Match-Up: How Different Are Google and Bing?
headline.main: A Search Engine Match-Up: How Different Are Google and Bing?

docs.snippet: To take on Google, Microsoft is spending billions to make its search engine the intelligent “decision engine.”...

headline.seo: With the Bing Search Engine, Microsoft Plays the Underdog
headline.main: Can Microsoft Make You ‘Bing’?
